title: Set up
text: First, set up the hypothesis test. Since the problem is about a mean, this is a test of a single population mean.
speech: First, set up the hypothesis test. Since the problem is about a mean, this is a test of a single population mean.
pacedSpeech: First, set up the hypothesis test. Since the problem is about a mean, this is a test of a single population mean.

title: Tail
text: A 5% level of significance means that $$\alpha=0.05$$. Based on the problem, $$H_0$$: $$μ=65$$ and $$H_a$$: $$μ>65$$. Therefore, this is a right-tailed test.
speech: A 5% level of significance means that  alpha is equal to, 0.05 . Based on the problem,    h sub 0 :  mu is equal to 65  and    h sub a :  mu is greater than 65 . Therefore, this is a right-tailed test.

. Based on the problem,     h sub 0

:   mu is greater than 65

title: Distribution
text: Determine the distribution needed. No population standard deviation given, and you are only given $$n=10$$ sample data values.
speech: Determine the distribution needed. No population standard deviation given, and you are only given  n is equal to 10,  sample data values.
pacedSpeech: Determine the distribution needed. No population standard deviation given, and you are only given   n is equal to 10,
sample data values.

title: Distribution
text: Use $$t_{df}$$. Therefore, the distribution for the test is $$t_9$$ where $$n=10$$ and $$df=10-1=9$$. Now, calculate the $$p-value$$ using the Student's $$t-distribution$$.
speech: Use  t sub d f end sub . Therefore, the distribution for the test is  t sub 9  where  n is equal to, 10  and  d f, is equal to 10 minus 1, is equal to 9 . Now, calculate the  p, minus value  using the Student's  t, minus distribution .

title: P-value
text: $$p-value=P\left(x>67\right)=0.0396$$ where the sample mean and sample standard deviation are calculated as $$67$$ and $$3.1972$$ from the data.

title: Compare
speech: Compare \alpha and the  p minus value, .

title: Compare
text: Is \alpha less than or greater than the $$p-value$$?
speech: Is \alpha less than or greater than the  p minus value, ?
pacedSpeech: Is \alpha less than or greater than the   p minus value,

title: Interpret
text: Since \alpha>p-value, we would reject $$H_0$$. This means you reject $$μ=65$$. In other words, you believe the average test score is greater than $$65$$.
speech: Since \alpha>p-value, we would reject    h sub 0 . This means you reject  mu, is equal to 65 . In other words, you believe the average test score is greater than  65 .
